docs.snippet: In a rare formal reprimand, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences disciplined one of the film's producers for violating the group's campaign rules....
docs.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES - "The Hurt Locker," a presumed front-runner in the Oscar race since picking up a string of honors from critics and the Hollywood guilds, suffered a last-minute embarrassment on Tuesday as the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences disciplined one of the film's producers for violating the group's campaign rules.
docs.abstract: In a rare formal reprimand, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences disciplined one of the film's producers for violating the group's campaign rules.

headline.main: 'Hurt Locker' Producer is Barred From Oscar Ceremony

docs.snippet: The costume designer who received her fourth Oscar nomination for "Bright Star" discusses Keats, 19th-century fashion, and her elusiveness....
docs.lead_paragraph: You've probably never heard of Janet Patterson, the costume designer who received her fourth Oscar nomination for "Bright Star," a quiet meditation on the unconsummated love affair between Fanny Brawne and the poet John Keats. With a résumé that includes "The Piano" (1993), Patterson is revered by industry peers, few of whom have met her. Far from prolific, she retreats between movies for years at a time. So it was a surprise when, 13 years after my first approach to interview her, she responded to yet another e-mail entreaty by calling from her home in Sydney, Australia.
docs.abstract: The costume designer who received her fourth Oscar nomination for "Bright Star" discusses Keats, 19th-century fashion, and her elusiveness.

headline.main: Now Nominating | Costume Designer Janet Patterson

docs.snippet: One sure-fire way to be recognized by the Academy is to go the inebriated route on screen....
docs.lead_paragraph: "I'm wondering if you could fit 'Moët and Chandon as the official Champagne of the Oscars' somewhere in your Carpetbagger coverage?" a publicist called to ask. Excellent timing: we were just working on a post about reckless drunks. Apparently acting like one is a quick route to Oscar glory, as Tom O'Neil notes on The Los Angeles Times Gold Derby blog.
docs.abstract: One sure-fire way to be recognized by the Academy is to go the inebriated route on screen.

docs.snippet: The Avatar/Pocahontas mash-up to end all mash-ups....
docs.lead_paragraph: As the Carpetbagger notes, we are deep into the silly season, with Oscar campaigning now veering into a debate over the military efficacy of "Hurt Locker." The scurrilous tactics rarely change the outcome, so we prefer to walk on the sunny side of the awards season. To wit, when we first saw "Avatar," it put us in the mind of "Dances with Wolves," but the Internet has spoken and the designated analogue is actually "Pocahontas," with a series of the inevitable mash-ups quickly following. But none, as Awards Daily points out, match this one for sheer brilliance of juxtaposition:
docs.abstract: The Avatar/Pocahontas mash-up to end all mash-ups.

docs.snippet: Although the Bagger doubted anybody would stoop to scare tactics to win an Oscar, the director Darren Aronofsky filled her in with what he had to deal with last year....
docs.lead_paragraph: There are mere hours to go until the Oscar polls close, which means all that dirty pool better have done its job by now. Like most sane people, the Bagger doubted that anybody would stoop to whisper campaigns or scare tactics in pursuit of a little gold man, but apparently both are perennial awards-race fixtures. Though he said he was too busy finishing his movie "Black Swan" to pay attention to the Oscar machinations this season (he did vote, however), the director Darren Aronofsky recently clued the Bagger into what he went through when he was promoting "The Wrestler" last year. "There was some Web sites spreading this thing about how a hundred people had walked out of a screening because of the violence," Mr. Aronofsky said. "Maybe that happened, I have no idea. What people told me is it didn't happen, or like three people walked out and they were all over 70 or something, which is understandable because the film was very violent. But it got picked up and spread around."
docs.abstract: Although the Bagger doubted anybody would stoop to scare tactics to win an Oscar, the director Darren Aronofsky filled her in with what he had to deal with last year.

docs.snippet: As the Oscar world chatters about the possible penalty for a producer's e-mail misstep, Movieline proposes some potential penalties....
docs.lead_paragraph: Not that Hollywood isn't adept at coming up with its own punishments - what was that latest Michael Bay movie? - but over at Movieline, the Bagger's pal Mark Lisanti serves up some potential penalties for Nicolas Chartier, the overeager "Hurt Locker" producer who offended the Academy with an e-mail message dissing the (unnamed) competition, "so that we can all get back to the important business of celebrating the underappreciated millionaires toiling in the obscurity of history's most glamorous industry." (Hear hear!)
docs.abstract: As the Oscar world chatters about the possible penalty for a producer's e-mail misstep, Movieline proposes some potential penalties.

docs.snippet: "A Town Called Panic" is a Belgian stop-motion animated film starring three enterprising toys: a cowboy, an Indian and a horse. Tonight the movie will be screened as part of the French Institute Alliance Française's ode to Belgian cinema. The...
docs.lead_paragraph: "A Town Called Panic" is a Belgian stop-motion animated film starring three enterprising toys: a cowboy, an Indian and a horse. Tonight the movie will be screened as part of the French Institute Alliance Française's ode to Belgian cinema. The series, which runs Tuesdays throughout March, also includes a screening of "When the Sea Rises" which earned director Yolande Moreau two Césars (that's the French equivalent of the Oscar). We recommend a dinner of waffles and Stella Artois beforehand.
